Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 09:50PM loriestelle wrote: I am having a bilateral nipple sparing masectomy May 8th.  Diagnosed with DCIS, but the lump is large and palpable so the BS thinks there's a chance there could be invasion.  I have very dense, fibrocystic lumps and mammograms have always been impossible to read.  She can't read the mammo or the MRI completly.    My question.  I liked the doctor so much, I didn't get a second opinion.  But she works with a plastic surgeon who seems to know his stuff...but who I'm personally not feeling it with.  Surgery is at 10 am but I was told to be at the hospital at 7am.  PS assistant called today to see if I could come to his office around 7:30 am before my surgery.  Then head to the hospital.  He needs to mark the breasts for the surgeon, but as his employee told me...the timing...is such that he'd have to sit around the hospital waiting if he came that early before surgery.  Or he'd have to go back and forth.  Which is what he wants me to do.  On the morning I'm going to have my breasts removed.  His office asks me something like this.  I just feel it was so insensitive and unreasonable, it makes me wish I had a different doctor.   I don't know how this works, but it seems to me that the surgeon's down time shouldn't be my problem.  I can't drive an hour away to the PS office at 6am the morning of my surgery.  Then drive back in terrible rush hour to go have surgery.  Isn't this stressful enough without a doctor asking me this?   I called my Breast Surgeon who said she would just do the markings after speaking to him.  Is this acceptable?  Is it something the PS should do?  I don't want my doctor skipping a step because it's inconvenient.  Anyone have an answer on this.  Please help.  It's a bit late to find another doctor.
